defs.docs: Semi-hierarchical configuration so con-free, it's unreal.

attributes.value: / Semi-hierarchical configuration so con-free, it's unreal.
/ use figment::{Figment, providers::{Format, Toml, Json, Env}};
/   * [Overview](#overview) - A brief overview of the entire crate.
/   * [Crate Feature Flags](#crate-feature-flags) - Feature flags and what
/   * [For Library Authors](#for-library-authors) - Brief guide for authors
/     wishing to use Figment in their libraries or frameworks.
/     authors of applications that use libraries that use Figment.
/   * [Tips](#tips) - Things to remember when working with Figment.
/ Figment is a library for declaring and combining configuration sources and
/ extracting typed values from the combined sources. There are two prevailing
/   * **Figments:** The [`Figment`] type, which combines providers via
/ Defining a configuration consists of constructing a `Figment` and merging or
/ joining any number of [`Provider`]s. Values for duplicate keys from a
/ _merged_ provider replace those from previous providers, while no
/ replacement occurs for _joined_ providers. Sources are read eagerly,
/ The simplest useful figment has one provider. The figment below will use all
/ environment variables prefixed with `MY_APP_` as configuration values, after
/ Most figments will use more than one provider, merging and joining as
/ necessary. The figment below reads `App.toml`, environment variables
/ prefixed with `APP_` and fills any holes (but does replace existing values)
/ use figment::{Figment, providers::{Format, Toml, Json, Env}};
/ Values can be [`extracted`](Figment::extract()) into any value that
/ semi-sandboxed configuration testing. The example below showcases
/ use figment::{Figment, providers::{Format, Toml, Json, Env}};
/     // Sources are read _eagerly_: sources are read as soon as they are
/ Figment takes _great_ care to propagate as much information as possible
/ about configuration sources. All values extracted from a figment are
/ [`Profile`]. The tag is preserved across merges, joins, and errors, which
/ also include the [`path`](Error::path) of the offending key. Precise
/ tracking allows for rich error messages as well as ["magic"] values like
/ [`RelativePathBuf`], which automatically creates a path relative to the
/ configuration file in which it was declared.
/   * The name of the configuration source.
/   * An ["interpolater"](Metadata::interpolate()) that takes a path to a key
/     and converts it into a provider-native key.
/   * A [`Source`] specifying where the value was sourced from.
/   * A code source [`Location`] where the value's provider was added to a
/ Along with the information in an [`Error`], this means figment can produce
/ error: invalid type: found string "hi", expected u16
/ extracting, and the dictionary corresponding to that profile is deserialized
/ into the requested type. If no profile is selected, the
/ There are two built-in profiles: the aforementioned default profile and the
/ [`Global`](Profile::Global) profile. As the name implies, the default
/ profile contains default values for all profiles. The global profile _also_
/ contains values that correspond to all profiles, but those values supersede
/ values of any other profile _except_ the global profile, even when another
/ Some providers can be configured as `nested`, which allows top-level keys in
/ dictionaries produced by the source to be treated as profiles. The following
/ use figment::{Figment, providers::{Format, Toml, Json, Env}};
/     // Note the `nested` option on both `file` providers. This makes each
/     // top-level dictionary act as a profile.
/     // The default profile is used...by default.
/     // A different profile can be selected with `select`.
/     // Selecting non-existent profiles is okay as long as we have defaults.
/     // Replace the previous `Base.toml`. This one has a `global` profile.
/     // Global values override all profile values.
/     // Merges from succeeding providers take precedence, even for globals.
/ To help with compilation times, types, modules, and providers are gated by
/ In addition to the four gated providers, figment provides the following
/ | [`(impl AsRef<str>, impl Serialize)`] | Global source from a `("key", value)`. |
/ | [`&T` _where_ `T: Provider`]          | Source from `T` as a reference.        |
/ The [`Provider`] trait documentation details extensively how to implement a
/ provider for Figment. For data format based providers, the [`Format`] trait
/ For libraries and frameworks that wish to expose customizable configuration,
/ use figment::{Figment, Provider, Error, Metadata, Profile};
/ struct Config { /* the library's required/expected values */ }
/     // Allow the configuration to be extracted from any `Provider`.
/     fn from<T: Provider>(provider: T) -> Result<Config, Error> {
/         // In reality, whatever the library desires.
/ // Make `Config` a provider itself for composability.
/         // Optionally, a profile that's selected by default.
/ This structure has the following properties:
/   * The library provides a `Config` structure that clearly indicates which
/   * Users can completely customize configuration via their own [`Provider`].
/   * The library's `Config` is itself a [`Provider`] for composability.
/   * The library provides a `Figment` which it will use as the default
/ `Config::from(Config::figment())` can be used as the library default while
/ allowing complete customization of the configuration sources. Developers
/ building on the library can base their figments on `Config::default()`,
/ For frameworks, a top-level structure should expose the `Figment` that was
/ used to extract the `Config`, allowing other libraries making use of the
/ framework to also extract values from the same `Figment`:
/ #     fn from<T: Provider>(_: T) -> Result<Config, Error> { panic!() }
/     /// The figment used to extract the configuration.
/     pub fn custom<T: Provider>(provider: T) -> Result<App, Error> {
/ As an application author, you'll need to make at least the following
/   1. The sources you'll accept configuration from.
/   2. The precedence you'll apply to each source.
/   3. Whether you'll use profiles or not.
/ For special sources, you may find yourself needing to implement a custom
/ [`Provider`]. As with libraries, you'll likely want to provide default
/ values where possible either by providing it to the figment or by using
/ matter of declaring a figment and extracting the configuration from it.
/ A reasonable starting point might be:
/ use figment::{Figment, providers::{Env, Format, Toml, Serialized}};
/ Some things to remember when working with Figment:
/   * Merging and joining are _eager_: sources are read immediately. It's
/     useful to define a function that returns a `Figment`.
/   * The [`util`] modules contains helpful serialize and deserialize
/   * The [`Format`] trait makes implementing data-format based [`Provider`]s
/   * [`Magic`](value::magic) values can significantly reduce the need to
/   * [`Jail`] makes testing configurations straight-forward and much less
/   * [`Error`] may contain more than one error: iterate over it to retrieve

defs.name: Value
defs.value:
pub enum Value {
    String(Tag, String),
    Char(Tag, char),
    Bool(Tag, bool),
    Num(Tag, Num),
    Empty(Tag, Empty),
    Dict(Tag, Dict),
    Array(Tag, Vec<Value>),
}
defs.docs: An enum representing all possible figment value variants.

defs.name: find
defs.docs:
Looks up and returns the value at path `path`, where `path` is of the
 form `a.b.c` where `a`, `b`, and `c` are keys to dictionaries. If the
 key is empty, simply returns `self`. If the key is not empty and `self`
 or any of the values for non-leaf keys in the path are not dictionaries,
 returns `None`.

 variants [`Actual::Float`]. Values exceeding the bit-width of the target
 [`Actual`] are truncated.

defs.name: RelativePathBuf
defs.docs: A [`PathBuf`] that knows the path of the file it was configured in, if any.

attributes.value: / A [`PathBuf`] that knows the path of the file it was configured in, if any.
/ Paths in configuration files are often desired to be relative to the
/ configuration file itself. For example, a path of `a/b.html` configured in a
/ file `/var/config.toml` might be desired to resolve as `/var/a/b.html`. This
/ type makes this possible by simply delcaring the configuration value's type
/     // Note that `jail.directory()` is some non-empty path:
/     // When a path is declared in a file and deserialized as
/     // `RelativePathBuf`, `relative()` will be relative to the file.
/     // If a path is declared elsewhere, the "relative" path is the original.
/     // You can use the `From<P: AsRef<Path>>` impl to set defaults:
/ By default, a `RelativePathBuf` serializes into a structure that can only
/ deserialize as a `RelativePathBuf`. In particular, a `RelativePathBuf` does
/ not serialize into a value compatible with `PathBuf`. To serialize into a
/     // Create a figment with a serialize `Config`.
/     // These succeed. This one uses the originally written path.
/     // This one the magic relative path.

defs.name: Serialized
defs.docs: A `Provider` that sources values directly from a serialize type.

attributes.value: / A `Provider` that sources values directly from a serialize type.
/     This provider does not set a profile.
/     This provider is named `T` (via [`std::any::type_name`]). The source
/     location is set to the call site of the constructor.
/     When data is not keyed, `T` is expected to serialize to a [`Dict`] and
/     is emitted directly as the value for the configured profile.
/     [`Serialized::key()`]), `T` can serialize to any [`Value`] and is
/     emitted as the value of the configured `key`. Specifically, nested
/     dictionaries are created for every path component delimited by `.` in
/     the key string (3 in `a.b.c`), each dictionary mapping to its parent,
/     and the serialized `T` mapping to the leaf.

defs.name: Data
defs.docs:
A `Provider` that sources values from a file or string in a given
 [`Format`].

attributes.value: / A `Provider` that sources values from a file or string in a given
/ A `Data` provider is typically constructed indirectly via a type that
/ implements the [`Format`] trait via the [`Format::file()`] and
/ [`Format::string()`] methods which in-turn defer to [`Data::file()`] and
/ // The `Format` trait must be in-scope to use its methods.
/ // These two are equivalaent, except the former requires the explicit type.
/     This provider does not set a profile.
/     This provider is named `${NAME} file` (when constructed via
/     constructed from a file, the file's path is specified as file
/     [`Source`](crate::Source). Path interpolation is unchanged from the
/     When nesting is _not_ specified, the source file or string is read and
/     parsed, and the parsed dictionary is emitted into the profile
/     [`Profile::Default`]. If the source is a file and the file is not
/     present, an empty dictionary is emitted.
/     When nesting is specified, the source value is exepcted to be a
/     dictionary. It's top-level keys are emitted as profiles, and the value
/     corresponding to each key as the profile data.

defs.name: file
defs.docs:
Returns a `Data` provider that sources its values by parsing the file at
 `path` as format `F`. If `path` is relative, the file is searched for in
 the current working directory and all parent directories until the root,
 and the first hit is used.

defs.name: Format
defs.docs: Trait implementable by text-based [`Data`] format providers.

attributes.value: / Trait implementable by text-based [`Data`] format providers.
/ Instead of implementing [`Provider`] directly, types that refer to data
/ formats, such as [`Json`] and [`Toml`], implement this trait. By
/ implementing [`Format`], they become [`Provider`]s indirectly via the
/ [`Data`] type, which serves as a provider for all `T: Format`.
/ #     fn from_str<'de, T: DeserializeOwned>(_: &'de str) -> Result<T, Self::Error> { todo!() }
/ There are two primary implementation items:
/   1. [`Format::NAME`]: This should be the name of the data format: `"JSON"`
/      or `"TOML"`. The string is used in the [metadata for `Data`].
/   2. [`Format::from_str()`]: This is the core string deserialization method.
/      A typical implementation will simply call an existing method like
/      [`toml::from_str`]. For writing a custom data format, see [serde's
/ and [`Format::string()`] methods should likely not be overwritten.
/ [serde's writing a data format guide]: https://serde.rs/data-format.html

defs.name: Toml
Env
defs.docs: A [`Provider`] that sources its values from environment variables.

attributes.value: / A [`Provider`] that sources its values from environment variables.
/ All key-lookups and comparisons are case insensitive, facilitated by the
/ [`UncasedStr`] and [`Uncased`] types. Environment variable names are
/ converted to lowercase before being emitted as [key paths] in the provided
/ data. Environment variable values can contain structured data, parsed as a
/ Additionally, strings delimited with `"` can contain the following escaped
/ Undelimited strings, or strings with invalid escape sequences, are
/ interpreted exactly as written without any escaping.
/ Because environment variables names are emitted as [key paths] in the
/ provided data, a nested dictionary is created for every component of the
/ name delimited by `.`, each a parent of the next, with the leaf mapping to
/ environment variable `Value`. For example, the environment variable
/ `a.b.c=3` creates the mapping `a -> b -> c -> 3` in the emitted data.
/ Environment variable names cannot typically contain the `.` character, but
/ another character can be used in its place by replacing that character in
/ the name with `.` with [`Env::map()`]. The [`Env::split()`] method is a
/ convenience method that does exactly this.
/     This provider does not set a profile.
/     This provider is named `environment variable(s)`. It does not specify a
/     [`Source`](crate::Source). Interpolation makes path parts uppercase and
/     The data emitted by this provider is single-level dictionary with the
/     keys and values returned by [`Env::iter()`], which reads from the
/     currently set environment variables and is customizable via the various
/     inherent methods. The dictionary is emitted to the profile

defs.docs:
Splits each environment variable key at `pattern`, creating nested
 dictionaries for each split. Specifically, nested dictionaries are
 created for components delimited by `pattern` in the environment
 variable string (3 in `A_B_C` if `pattern` is `_`), each dictionary
 mapping to its parent.

defs.name: Error
defs.docs: An error that occured while producing data or extracting a configuration.

attributes.value: / An error that occured while producing data or extracting a configuration.
/ An `Error` will generally be constructed indirectly via its implementations
/ of serde's [`de::Error`] and [`ser::Error`], that is, as a result of
/ serialization or deserialization errors. When implementing [`Provider`],
/ however, it may be necessary to construct an `Error` directly.
/ Broadly, there are two ways to construct an `Error`:
/   * Via an error message, since `Error` impls `From<String>`:
/ As always, `?` can be used to automatically convert into an `Error` using
/ By default, `Error` uses all of the available information about the error,
/ including the `Metadata`, `path`, and `profile` to display a message that
/ resembles the following, where `$` is `error.` for some `error: Error`:
/ Concretely, such an error may look like:
/ invalid type: found sequence, expected u16: `staging.port` in TOML file Config.toml
/ An `Error` may contain more than one error. To process all errors, iterate

defs.name: Kind
defs.value:
pub enum Kind {
    Message(String),
    InvalidType(Actual, String),
    InvalidValue(Actual, String),
    InvalidLength(usize, String),
    UnknownVariant(String, &'static [&'static str]),
    UnknownField(String, &'static [&'static str]),
    MissingField(Cow),
    DuplicateField(&'static str),
    ISizeOutOfRange(isize),
    USizeOutOfRange(usize),
    Unsupported(Actual),
    UnsupportedKey(Actual, Cow),
}

}

defs.name: bool_from_str_or_int

defs.docs: A helper to deserialize `0/false` as `false` and `1/true` as `true`.

attributes.value: / A helper to deserialize `0/false` as `false` and `1/true` as `true`.
/ Serde's default deserializer for `bool` only parses the strings `"true"` and
/ `"false"` as the booleans `true` and `false`, respectively. By contract,
/ this function _case-insensitively_ parses both the strings `"true"/"false"`
/ and the integers `1/0` as the booleans `true/false`, respectively.

defs.name: Figment
defs.docs: Combiner of [`Provider`]s for configuration value extraction.

attributes.value: / Combiner of [`Provider`]s for configuration value extraction.
/ A `Figment` combines providers by merging or joining their provided data.
/ The combined value or a subset of the combined value can be extracted into
/ any type that implements [`Deserialize`]. Additionally, values can be nested
/ in _profiles_, and a profile can be selected via [`Figment::select()`] for
/ extraction; the profile to be extracted can be retrieved with
/ docs](crate) contain a broad overview of these topics.
/ _Merging_ and _joining_ control whether duplicate values are replaced or
/ discarded. A _merged_ value replaces an existing value with the same key,
/ while a _joined_ value is discarded if a value with the same key exists:
/ The configuration or a subset thereof can be extracted from a `Figment` in
/   * [`Figment::extract()`], which extracts the complete value into any `T:
/   * [`Figment::extract_inner()`], which extracts a subset of the value for a
/ A "key path" is a string of the form `a.b.c` (e.g, `item`, `item.fruits`,
/ etc.) where each component delimited by a `.` is a key for the dictionary of
/ the preceding key in the path, or the root dictionary if it is the first key
/ in the path. See [`Value::find()`] for examples.
/ Every value collected by a `Figment` is accompanied by the metadata produced
/ by the value's provider. Additionally, [`Metadata::provide_location`] is set
/ by `from`, `merge` and `join` to the caller's location. `Metadata` can be
/ retrieved in one of several ways:
/   * [`Figment::metadata()`], which returns an iterator over all of the
/   * [`Figment::find_metadata()`], which returns the metadata for a value at
/   * [`Figment::get_metadata()`], which returns the metadata for a given

defs.name: Metadata
defs.docs: Metadata about a configuration value: its source's name and location.

attributes.value: / Metadata about a configuration value: its source's name and location.
/ Every [`Value`] produced by a [`Figment`] is [`Tag`]ed with `Metadata`
/ by its producing [`Provider`]. The metadata consists of:
/   * A name for the source, e.g. "TOML File".
/   * The [`Source`] itself, if it is known.
/   * A source [`Location`] where a value's provider was added to the
/   containing figment, if it is known.
/ This information is used to produce insightful error messages as well as to
/ generate values like [`RelativePathBuf`] that know about their configuration
/ [`Error`]s produced by [`Figment`]s contain the `Metadata` for the value
/ that caused the error. The `Display` implementation for `Error` uses the
/ metadata's interpolater to display the path to the key for the value that
/ Interpolation takes a figment profile and key path (`a.b.c`) and turns it
/ into a source-native path. The default interpolater returns a figment key
/ path prefixed with the profile if the profile is custom:
/ Providers are free to implement any interpolater for their metadata. For
/ example, the interpolater for [`Env`] uppercases each path key:

The source location where this value's provider was added to the
 containing figment, if it is known.

/ containing figment, if it is known.

defs.name: Provider
defs.docs: Trait implemented by configuration source providers.

attributes.value: / Trait implemented by configuration source providers.
/ For an overview of built-in providers, see the [top-level
/ A [`Provider`] reads from a source to provide configuration data for
/ to identify the source of its configuration data ([`Provider::metadata()`]).
/ A provider may also optionally set a `Profile` for the `Figment` it is
/ merged (but not joined) into by implementing [`Provider::profile()`].
/ A [`Provider`] meant to be consumed externally should allow for optional
/ is to allow a `Profile` to be specified. If one is not, read the
/ configuration data as a `Map<Profile, Dict>`, thus using the top-level keys
/ as profiles. If one _is_ specified, read the data as `Dict` and
/ Implementing a `Provider` requires implementing methods that provide both of
/ these pieces of data. The first, [`Provider::metadata()`] identifies the
/ provider's configuration sources, if any, and allows the provider to
/ customize how paths to keys are interpolated. The second,
/ [`Provider::data()`], actually reads the configuration and returns the data.
/ As an example, consider a provider that reads configuration from a
/ networked store at some `Url`. A `Provider` implementation for such a
/ use figment::{Provider, Metadata, Profile, Error, value::{Map, Dict}};
/ /// A provider that fetches its data from a given URL.
/     /// The profile to emit data to if nesting is disabled.
/     /// The url to fetch data from.
/     /// Returns metadata with kind `Network`, custom source `self.url`,
/     /// and interpolator that returns a URL of `url/a/b/c` for key `a.b.c`.
/     /// Fetches the data from `self.url`. Note that `Dict`, `Map`, and
/     /// `Profile` are `Deserialize`, so we can deserialized to them.
/         fn fetch<'a, T: Deserialize<'a>>(url: &Url) -> Result<T, Error> {
/             /* fetch from the network, deserialize into `T` */
